"An option to blur and/or hide peoples avatars in the comments would be great, to hide the spam bot thirst traps"

I very rarely need buttons for a clip, report, etc. I mostly use the save button. It would be nice if I could have just this one button.

so can we replace an "Hide extra buttons" in video section for each of a kind? a

title: Suggestion Wall (End of the Video) is displaced with TubeMod enabled
body:
As the title says, at the end of a video the suggestion wall is displaced to the bottom right corner of the video player for some reason, even though I don't use the _"Hide Suggestion Wall (End of the Video)"_ feature (or any other feature under the _"Video"_ section).

I've only started seeing this bug since yesterday, when YouTube changed the progress bar colour, so it could be a server side change that caused this bug.
author: RandomPersonUMet

comments.body: Nevermind just realised that this has been resolved and I just haven't gotten the update yet.
Yep, the fix is coming tonight, alongside a new version :)

title: Suggestion Wall Bug
body: The suggestions wall is pushed to the bottom right corner of the video player and only shows 4 videos with the rest all out of frame

Fixed, to be deployed tonight ðŸ˜„

title: Hide Youtube Footer Bug

author: SolarIDK

title: Feat: Remove Elements
body:
Finally done!

Adds the ability to toggle between removing the elements from the DOM or hiding them with CSS (already implemented). It is configured by a toggle that appears in first position in the UI.

In my testing in works fine, however it doesn't completely delete the elements before they are loaded, and it seems to be a bit delayed. Maybe that could be fixed in later iterations, but for now, I can't seem to find a way to achieve it.

Also, I suck at writing JS so it might have some issues. I however, didn't find any.
author: Perseus333

comments.body: What a banger! Thanks for this, @Perseus333 !

> Nice feature, cleaning the DOM is better imo, but I am wondering if this option will be useful for users ? What would this mean for them ?

This means from my testing much less GPU consumption (can go down to 0 if you remove everything lol) and a bit less memory usage. It's useful just for that lol, only impactful if you remove lots of elements though like thumbnails or so. So maybe it could be activated just for those? Idk.

Yeah clearly there's a benefit to it, but the option in itself seems weird to me, why would you let the user choose one or the other ? There is no good answer, or I just don't see it.
And for the GPU consumption this is good but doesn't mean a lot right now, this is largely compensated by other things as the extension isn't designed to do this much.

You could keep it this way at the moment and maybe mark this feature as "experimental" ?
I'm _slowwwly_ working on performance improvements, trying to get rid of the popping behavior, if I get this right I think it would be time to make this the default behavior and cleanup the hiding part

> Yeah clearly there's a benefit to it, but the option in itself seems weird to me, why would you let the user choose one or the other ? There is no good answer, or I just don't see it. And for the GPU consumption this is good but doesn't mean a lot right now, this is largely compensated by other things as the extension isn't designed to do this much.

Yes, you are right that it gives more decisions to make for the user and that can hinder the experience marginally, but it also improves it marginally. But I see your point that it isn't something that makes much of a difference for the user.

> You could keep it this way at the moment and maybe mark this feature as "experimental" ? I'm _slowwwly_ working on performance improvements, trying to get rid of the popping behavior, if I get this right I think it would be time to make this the default behavior and cleanup the hiding part

The thing with this being the default behavior is that you have to reload the website for you to see the results, and that's why the hiding method is snappier. This is the reason I put this toggle, to let the user decide. 

However, a better idea could be to maybe place in in the end? As an option for more advanced users if they want this extra degree of customization.

Good morning, everyone!
I've not yet reviewed the PR changes thoroughly, but let's talk about a couple of things:
- Shoutout to @Perseus333 for trying out new things! And shoutout to @Myouboku for keeping an eye on the project! You're both killing it!
- This one is a hard feature to ship, and we got to fully understand the nuances of implementing something like this. We'll need some data and comparisons to properly conclude about the way we're doing this (hiding vs. removing vs. preventing from loading).
- Hiding elements means they keep loading in the background (check the next example); How's the case when we're removing them from the DOM? Are they being added again? Are the requests for those elements still being done in the background? Or is the request done when loading the page in the first place (this is probably not the case)?
  - Consider the following scenario: I'm using TubeMod and decided to hide suggested videos. When I'm scrolling through the comments, what happens in the background if I have them hidden? What if I have them removed?Â 
  - To raise some conclusions about the benefits of removing elements vs. simply hiding them, here's an idea: Use the same video and the same starting point, which should be the initial page load. Pause the video, let it load up to the point where the play bar stops progressing, and start testing by hiding the suggested videos and scrolling to the bottom of the comments. How long did it take? What does the network tab say about the loading speed? Repeat the same process when deleting the suggested videos. This isn't perfect (the internet speed and the machine performance are variables), but it should allow us to reach some conclusions.
- Another possible approach (and possibly more demanding; therefore, out of the scope of this PR) would be preventing the requests from being done in the first place. If requests are blocked, there's less resources being retrieved, which means the page would be ready faster.
- Removing elements should 100% be an option for users to toggle or simply check, for one simple reason: it changes the way they interact with YouTube. TubeMod hides things, which means we can bring them back at any time because they are already there, just hidden. Removing content means the DOM is updated, and to bring them back, users need to reload the page, changing how they interact with both the extension and YouTube itself.
- Removing elements is something only a small number of users would use, I believe. Therefore, I also think this should be under an advanced section in the popup. We may also be starting to need a proper settings page, given the amount of things we have to hide (again, this is out of scope of this PR; don't worry about it) ðŸ˜† 

Nevertheless, thank you both for talking about stuff and bringing news ideias to the table. Also, please, don't take anything that I said as an universal truth, remember I'm still learning as well! These were just my two cents on what we're talking about :)

Thanks @Pedro-Gregorio! Great ideas! You are right that this is a very complex feature if implemented thoroughly. I can run some of the tests that you've mentioned on my machine and publish the results here. I'll also try to see if I can implement a way to prevent them from loading in the first place. Looking forward to this!

Just a heads up, if you test this make sure that you refresh the YouTube (if you had it open) after you load the extension for the first time, otherwise it will throw an error, and it has been driving me nuts for hours. :')
I have started this discussion ( #62 ) to discuss how to proceed about this

title: Hide video views homepage - v1.6
body:
Hides views from homepage.

Same as #36 but rebased to v1.6
author: Perseus333

comments.body: Sure! Tomorrow I'll check.
Appreciate that! The issue occurs for both the views and that posted x time ago.

> @Perseus333 Can you confirm this doesn't make views hide sometimes on the subscriptions page or on the channel page? Here's what I did: access youtube home page -> subscriptions -> home page -> back to subscriptions and the views were hidden.

You are right! What??! I know that this is because of the generic selector (which I will fix) but this shouldn't happen anyways. Due to the attribute(?): `pageTypes: [PAGE_TYPES.HOME],` it should only apply to the homepage and not the subscriptions. Maybe there is an issue with the handling of that?

(1 hour later)

I have found that the issue probably lies in that the eventListener `yt-navigate-finish` doesn't trigger when you go back to a cached(?) page. So this is most likely the source of the issue. I have tried several others like:
- yt-navigate-cache
- track
- transitioned
- load

And every single time nothing changes. @Pedro-Gregorio, if you know what could be the source of the issue tell me because right now I'm lost.

Hey there, @Perseus333 !
I've researched a bit for yesterday, but couldn't really figure out why that was happening - code wise; Page wise, it's due to the fact none of the events (load and navigate) are triggered on the scenario I've mentioned.
It's so wierd, because there are things from the home page (tabs, if I'm not mistaken) which used to mess up things on the subscriptions, until the page validation was implemented - which can be improved btw, I'm working on that. I really don't know what's going on.
I've also noticed a slight performance decrease with those 2 elements being hidden (views and time), but, again, I can't really conclude on why.
Anyways, thank you for confirming the error and don't worry about it for now, as I'll be working on trying to improve content.js and fix the issue :)
Great! I'll also continue researching to see if I can help you find the issue.

title: Adds option to hide amount of likes in the video
body:
It is a bit awkward for the moment because of one the parents has a margin that makes it not be centered enough when there is no number.

It could be fixed if the extension allowed for a way to modify the CSS, but for the moment this is all that can be done.
author: Perseus333

comments.body: Let's leave this on a draft, for now. I found (sort of) a way to fix the margin issue on Stream, this past Thursday, but I'm not ready yet to deploy it. I also believe this should replace the current hide - for the whole button itself. What's your opinion on this? ðŸ¤”

Well, for more customization it is better to have them both. If I had to choose though, I'd much rather hide the like amount than the whole like/dislike button, as it is more useful. So I'd agree if you only want to have an option for this, otherwise, I'd keep them both. 

By the way, since there some suggestions about hiding general parts rather than individual ones, I reckon in the future there should be a hierarchical list of all the options to toggle so that you could toggle all the sidebar at once, or all the likes/dislikes buttons at once, or just remove the value. I don't know how to even begin with that but I think it's the best way to go in the long-run.

I'll look forward to your streams!

Created a poll to see what way we should be going from now!

About that, I totally agree! I want to focus on organizing content overall in the next version (1.6.0), and making things properly organized and related. If you're hiding the suggested videos, you're also hiding the suggested shorts, and that should be visible, and soo on. But appreciate the feedback! :)
Hey @Perseus333 ! Sorry about this, but I deleted the 1.5.0 branch after merging it to master, ahead of the release. Could you please add this to the newly created 1.6.0?
Sure!

title: Add: Hide Sidebar
body: This commit hides the sidebar and the sidebar button.

comments.body: Hey @Rashnain ! Thank you for your contributions! I'll leave this on hold. Hiding the whole sidebar, as a concept, it's nice, but I want to do it more gracefully - the UI itself becomes wierd, with the huge space on the left, and hiding the sidebar as a whole is probably going to be done differently, because when we hide it, we also hide every other component, and that state should also be considered.

body: Just that. Although it leaves the dot between the views and the time since the video has been uploaded that I don't know how to remove because it is a ::before and apparently it cannot be removed with xpath.

comments.body: I'll leave this one for a future release. If we're hiding views, we should probably hide them everywhere - home, subscriptions, search, video (already implemented), recommended videos. This is probably one of the changes that will make me re-evaluate the performance of the extension. Nevertheless, thank you @Perseus333 for your help!

title: Fixed some sidebar buttons
body:
This pull request just aims to fix some issues related to the sidebar:

- Fix YouTube Shorts button in the sidebar not working for Firefox
- Added support to remove the "Courses" button
- Added a way to more robustly identify different elements in the sidebar by using their hrefs instead of their position.

Also, it adds a section in the readme to develop it in chrome or firefox based browsers.

Sorry for the revert commits, if you know how to delete them feel free to do so, because I don't.

Love your project btw! I will try to make more contributions in the future. :)
author: Perseus333

comments.body: Hey @Perseus333 ! Can you please rebase your branch to be accordingly to V1.5.0,  please? Thank you for those developer notes, saves me quite some time! And thank you for your contribution! <3
Yeah, sure!

In my eyes it seems redundant but maybe there's a reason?

Hello there! Thank you for reaching out, @Aquazu ! 

It doesn't... it's probably related to one of the permissions I need for it to work, but I am not using it anywhere. Unfortunately, that popup is misleading.

title: issue: Firefox Specific - Sidebar options bug
body:
There is a Firefox specific issue with disabling items in the sidebar. When trying to use an option to disable an element, the one above it gets disable instead.

Example:
Hide Playlists Button -> History Button is hidden
Hide Your Videos Button -> Playlists Button is hidden

The new "Hide YouTube Music" feature doesn't work in Firefox either.
Verified by getting a youtube premium free trial
Tested in Firefox Developer Edition and Opera GX (Worked fine in Opera)
author: ItzELECTR0

comments.body: Hey, @ItzELECTR0 ! Thank you for reaching out! Can you confirm that both browsers are using TubeMod in version 1.4.0?
Yes, both are using 1,4,0

According to @ItzELECTR0 , "unhook affected how TubeMod worked, since Unhooked already removed some elements, when I tried to remove others with TubeMod, they were misplaced. It was an easy fix by just disabling some of my options in Unhook."

title: feature request: Automatically set theatre mode for videos
body: As of late youtube has been resetting the theatre mode preference. A nice feature would be to automatically start playing videos in theatre mode.
author: ItzELECTR0

comments.body: Closing this as YouTube already performs this well enough, and better than I would ðŸ˜„
